text: - Welcome to 'Back To Basics'.
In this episode, we will explore

how self-service data
environments empower users
with simplified data access

while still maintaining governance
and compliance standards.

We'll discuss some of the
ways you can organize data

into domains or problem spaces
for more efficient access.

Self-service environments can
transform your organization

by limiting barriers like
gatekeepers and manual processes.
Let's see how this works.
Imagine a medical organization's data
scattered across unorganized silos.
It becomes an uphill task

where different teams
define relevant data sets.
Structuring data into functional domains
or virtual folders based on purpose

or characteristics of the data
can address these challenges.
For our medical organization,
they could have a patient data domain

focused on patient demographics
and treatment records,
a clinical domain for clinical data sets
and research findings,
and a finance data domain
dealing with financial payment records
related to patient billing.

Organizing data in this
way simplifies discovery

and access of relevant data
sets for different departments.

You can also align data
into value stream domains
based on specific business processes.
Within our medical organization,
you can see a patient care value stream

coordinating care delivery
across departments,
an operational efficiency domain
focusing on process optimization,
and a clinical research domain
concentrating on clinical trial data sets.
Next, let's take a look at the roles
within our self-service environment:
data producers and consumers.

Data producers curate
domain-specific data sets,

such as patient data with
quality control measures

like documentation and metadata
for streamlined discovery.

Producers publish these
assets into the data catalog,

specifying access controls
before sharing more broadly.
To maintain governance,

your data producers
labeled their data sets

with appropriate licensing
information, medical compliance,

and to find approval
controls before publishing.

Data consumers discover these
published assets tailored
to the role-specific tasks.
For instance, data scientists
might prefer Amazon SageMaker notebooks

while analysts opt for
Amazon QuickSight dashboards.

Lastly, consumers leverage
a business data catalog,

a searchable metadata catalog
defined available data sets
within their domains and access controls.

Now that we discuss
producers and consumers,

let's bring it all together
with Amazon DataZone.

Amazon DataZone is a
platform that allows you
to create self-service data environments
for your organization.

It consists of domains
which define the boundaries
for data sharing and consumption.
Domains can be aligned

with your organization's
departments or objectives,

such as patient care,
clinical research, or finance.

Fine-grained access controls
protect sensitive data
from unauthorized access.
You can set permissions at various levels

to ensure only authorized
individuals can view
or manipulate specific data sets.

Metadata catalogs enable
efficient discovery of data sets

through search functionality
based on specific licensing
or medical tagging taxonomy.

For example, Amazon DataZone
could simplify your process
of finding and using data

for informed decision-making
across various departments.
Amazon DataZone seamlessly integrates
with your existing systems
and workflows through APIs,

allowing easy connection
with custom medical solutions
or other analytics tools.

Self-service data environments
empower your users,

but require making
proper training available
for effective utilization.
Implementing self-service
with a lack of data quality controls
can lead to poor business outcomes,

making it essential for
you to implement processes
and tools for data profiling,
cleansing, validation, and monitoring.
And that's it:

protected and simplified
self-service data environments
with Amazon DataZone.

Check out the links in the
description for more details.
Thanks for watching 'Back to Basics'.
See you next time.
